head.headtext: Blackboards, diagrams, charts, models, posters, overhead projectors

para.paratext: A party may utilize items like blackboards, diagrams, posters, and overhead projectors to show the jury summaries and diagrams of evidence and legal issues.
In Teems v. State,[1] the court upheld a trial court's decision to allow a prosecutor to write the crimes charged and victims' names on a blackboard during opening statement.

In Lewyn v. Morris,[2] the Georgia Court of Appeals held that the trial court had “overstepped its bounds” in sustaining an objection to a blackboard diagram drawn by the plaintiff's lawyer during the opening statement to show the scene of a collision. The trial court sustained the objection based upon the mistaken belief that the diagram was improper “until there is evidence to that effect.”
In Wilson v. State,[3] the court allowed defense counsel to draw a diagram of the scene at issue on a blackboard and then use it to cross-examine prosecution witnesses.

Diagrams must fairly and accurately depict what they represent, but do not have to be drawn to scale as any inaccuracy or incompleteness can be brought out on cross examination as this does not affect admissibility but goes to the weight the jury will give the exhibit.[4]
In Jackson v. International Harvester Co.,[5] the court upheld the right of a plaintiff in a product liability case to use a model as a means of showing the jury what was at issue.
The Georgia Court of Appeals has approved counsel's use of charts showing excerpts of controlling law during closing argument before the jury.[6]

Models may be used to illustrate evidence. For example, a trial court admitted wooden models of machinery involved in litigation as demonstrative evidence to help the jury understand how the machinery worked.[7] An expert was properly allowed to show a videotape of a model he had built to explain electrical principles involved in the case.[8]

Posters and overhead slides of documents and material admitted into evidence can be shown to the jury during trial because jurors can properly see anything that has already been admitted and this approach is the most efficient way to show a piece of evidence to all jurors at one time.[9]
Lewyn v. Morris, 135 Ga. App. 289, 217 S.E.2d 642 (1975).
Wilson v. State, 188 Ga. App. 731, 374 S.E.2d 345 (1988).

Fountain v. DeKalb County, 154 Ga. App. 302, 304, 267 S.E.2d 903 (1980); Clarke County School Dist. v. Madden, 99 Ga. App. 670, 676–677, 110 S.E.2d 47 (1959); Rouse v. Fussell, 106 Ga. App. 259, 126 S.E.2d 830 (1962); Southern Ry. Co. v. Brock, 132 Ga. 858, 64 S.E. 1083 (1909).
Jackson v. International Harvester Co., 190 Ga. App. 765, 767, 380 S.E.2d 306 (1989).
Oglethorpe Power Corp. v. Sheriff, 210 Ga. App. 299, 303, 436 S.E.2d 14 (1993).
Jackson v. International Harvester Co., 190 Ga. App. 765, 380 S.E.2d 306 (1989).
Cottrell, Inc. v. Williams, 266 Ga. App. 357, 596 S.E.2d 789 (2004).

Posters and slides of prior inconsistent statements used to impeach witnesses can be shown to the witnesses and to the jury during the impeachment process because jurors can see what they can hear, and showing these statements to the jury has the effect of making the exercise more clear.
